Jeremy_McComb:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Jeremy McComb | image = | caption = | image_size = | birth_name = Jerome McComb | origin = [[Idaho (U.S. state)|Idaho]], United States | instrument = Vocals | genre = [[country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 2004–present | label = New Revolution | website = http://www.jeremymccomb.com/ }} '''Jerome "Jeremy" McComb''' (born in [[Idaho]]) is an American [[country music]] artist and former tour manager for comedian [[Larry the Cable Guy]]. In 2008, he signed to Parallel/New Revolution Records and released his debut album ''My Side of Town'' that year. This album produced the singles "Wagon Wheel", "This Town Needs a Bar" and "Cold". Although the first two singles did not chart, "Cold" has become his first entry on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, debuting at No. 58 in November. ==Biography== Jeremy McComb was born in Idaho.{{cite web|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26057_5836935,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130123154742/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26057_5836935,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 23, 2013 |title=Artists A to Z: Jeremy McComb biography |accessdate=November 4, 2008 |work=[[Great American Country]] }} His father, Bob, was a local musician who played six nights a week and regularly brought him to venues where he performed. McComb made his singing debut at age eight, when his father invited him to join him onstage to sing [[Willie Nelson]]'s "[[On the Road Again (Willie Nelson song)|On the Road Again]]". Later on, McComb found work as a music director and disc jockey at the radio station [[KFOO-FM|KIXZ-FM]] in [[Spokane, Washington]]. He then befriended comedian [[Larry the Cable Guy]] while working at the station, and was hired as the comedian's tour manager in 2004 at age 23.{{cite web|url=http://www.gac.tv/gac/nw_cma_close_up/article/0,3034,GAC_26068_5938466_,00.html |title=New Artist Spotlight – Jeremy McComb |accessdate=November 3, 2008 |last=Doerschuk |first=Bob |work=[[Great American Country]] }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web |url=http://magazine.angrycountry.com/article.php?story=20080205173036177 |title=Jeremy McComb – ''My Side of Town'' |accessdate=November 3, 2008 |date=February 5, 2008 |work=Angry Country |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707143804/http://magazine.angrycountry.com/article.php?story=20080205173036177 |archive-date=July 7, 2011 |url-status=dead }} McComb began working on his music while serving as Larry's manager. While with the comedian, he was introduced to J.P. Williams, the CEO of Parallel Entertainment. He was then sent to a studio in [[Spartanburg, South Carolina]], where he began recording his debut album. Initially, it was to have been released on a division of [[Warner Bros. Records]], but legal difficulties forced Williams to release it on his own label instead. Entitled ''My Side of Town'', it was released on Parallel/New Revolution in June 2008, and was produced by Paul Riddle of the [[Marshall Tucker Band]]. The first single from the album, "[[Wagon Wheel (song)|Wagon Wheel]]," was originally recorded by [[Bob Dylan]] and later by the [[Old Crow Medicine Show]] and [[Darius Rucker]]. Following it was "This Town Needs a Bar," which was written by [[Liz Rose]] and [[Jimmy Yeary]], and was originally featured in the soundtrack to the film ''[[Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector]]''.{{cite web |url=http://dishmag.com/issue79/music-film/7634/jeremy-mccomb-s-side-of-town/ |title=Jeremy McComb's side of town |accessdate=November 4, 2008 |last=Hollabuagh |first=Laurie |work=Dish Magazine}} The first two singles both failed to chart, although the third single, "Cold", debuted at number 58 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts in November 2008 and peaked at number 43. ''[[Country Weekly]]'' magazine gave ''My Side of Town'' three-and-a-half stars out of five, calling it "one of the year's most encouraging [albums]".{{cite web |url=http://www.countryweekly.com/jeremy_mccomb/reviews/526 |title=Jeremy McComb – ''My Side of Town'' |accessdate=November 3, 2008 |last=Chris |first=Neal |date=June 3, 2008|work=Country Weekly}} "Cold" received a favorable review from the country music review site Roughstock, whose critic Matt Bjorke called it "a ballad which details the difficulties that people sometimes have in getting over a relationship…McComb sings about feeling numb, or 'Cold' about the way that the relationship ended."{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/jeremy-mccomb-cold-(single) |title=Jeremy McComb – "Cold" |accessdate=November 4, 2008 |last=Bjorke |first=Matt |work=Roughstock |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120091922/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/jeremy-mccomb-cold-%28single%29 |archivedate=November 20, 2008 }} Following his major label debut McComb independently released an EP titled "Leap and the Net will Appear". Which included the song "Easy as breathing" co-written with [[Kevin Kadish]] ([[Meghan Trainor]] / [[Jason Mraz]] producer & collaborator) The song while never worked as a single picked up AirPlay across the country. ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:12em;"| Title ! style="width:18em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''My Side of Town'' | * Release date: May 13, 2008 * Label: Parallel/New Revolution |- ! scope="row"| ''Leap & the Net Will Appear'' | * Release date: October 11, 2011 * Label: McCombOVER Records |- !
